title: Cannot Install Charm With Spack 0.10.0
body:
Hi 

I cannot get charm to install.

The error:

```
==> Installing charm
==> Using cached archive: /pbtech_mounts/softlib001/apps/EL6/spack/var/spack/cache/charm/charm-6.7.1.tar.gz
==> Already staged charm-6.7.1-jhvopm2ldu3fi7xzinba4b2zbm472feo in /pbtech_mounts/softlib001/apps/EL6/spack/var/spack/stage/charm-6.7.1-jhvopm2ldu3fi7xzinba4b2zbm472feo
==> Already patched charm
==> Building charm [Package]
==> Executing phase : 'install'
==> Error: InstallError: Exactly one communication mechanism (+mpi, +multicore, +net, +netlrts, or +verbs) must be enabled
```

Though I am doing

```
spack install charm -smp -mpi +multicore %gcc@6.3.0
```

Which seems correct given

```
[god@heavenl ~]# spack info charm
Package:    charm
Homepage:   http://charmplusplus.org

Safe versions:  
    6.7.1    http://charm.cs.illinois.edu/distrib/charm-6.7.1.tar.gz
    6.7.0    http://charm.cs.illinois.edu/distrib/charm-6.7.0.tar.gz
    6.6.1    http://charm.cs.illinois.edu/distrib/charm-6.6.1.tar.gz
    6.6.0    http://charm.cs.illinois.edu/distrib/charm-6.6.0.tar.gz
    6.5.1    http://charm.cs.illinois.edu/distrib/charm-6.5.1.tar.gz

Variants:
    Name         Default   Description

    mpi          on        Use MPI as communication mechanism
    multicore    off       Disable inter-node communication
    net          off       Use net communication mechanism
    netlrts      on        Use netlrts communication mechanism
    papi         off       Enable PAPI integration
    smp          on        Enable SMP parallelism (does not work with +multicore)
    tcp          off       Use TCP as transport mechanism (requires +net)
    verbs        off       Use Infiniband as communication mechanism

Installation Phases:
    install

Build Dependencies:
    mpi  papi

Link Dependencies:
    mpi  papi

Run Dependencies:
    None

Virtual Packages: 
    None

Description:
    Charm++ is a parallel programming framework in C++ supported by an
    adaptive runtime system, which enhances user productivity and allows
    programs to run portably from small multicore computers (your laptop) to
    the largest supercomputers.
```


Any ideas?
